Note that the performance of energy storage/conversion devices highly relies on the properties of electrode materials. This greatly accelerates the development of novel electrode materials with unique structural characteristics and functions to achieve a further breakthrough of energy storage/conversion systems.[4a,7]
Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials, especially graphene, have drawn vast attention and shown great promise for a wide range of applications.[8] Inspired by the great achievements of graphene-related
researches in the past decade,[9] a number of graphene analogs have been synthesized and explored, especially 2D metal dichalcogenides (MDCs), which represent a big family of compounds with a generalized formula of MX2.[10] Due to the ultrathinness and 2D morphology, 2D MDCs with single- or few-layer thickness have shown some extraordinary properties in contrast to their bulk counterparts. First, some of the 2D MDCs exhibit layer-dependent bandgap. For example, an indirect band gap of 1.3 eV in bulk MoS2 converts into a direct band gap of 1.8 eV in the single-layer MoS2.[11] Second, similar to graphene, the ultrathin thickness and 2D morphology enable 2D MDCs with ultrahigh specific surface area compared to their bulk counterparts,[12] making them promising for those surface-active applications, such as electrocatalysis and supercapacitors. Third, 2D MDCs possess high flexibility and good mechanical strength in contrast to their bulk counterparts due to the unique 2D structural features.[13] Owing to these extraordinary properties, 2D MDCs have been explored for various promising applications in electronics/optoelectronics, sensors and biomedicine.[14] Specifically, the appealing features of 2D MDCs including highly exposed active edge sites, large specific surface area and easy to be intercalated by other guest materials render them favorable for energy storage/conversion applications like rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors, electrocatalytic hydrogen generation and solar cells.[15]

The development of renewable energy storage and conversion devices is one of the most promising ways to address the current energy crisis, along with the global environmental concern. The exploration of suitable active materials is the key factor for the construction of highly efficient, highly stable, lowcost and environmentally friendly energy storage and conversion devices. The ability to prepare two-dimensional (2D) metal dichalcogenide (MDC) nanosheets and their functional composites in high yield and large scale via various solution-based methods in recent years has inspired great research interests in their utilization for renewable energy storage and conversion applications. Here, we will summarize the recent advances of solutionprocessed 2D MDCs and their hybrid nanomaterials for energy storage and conversion applications, including rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors, electrocatalytic hydrogen generation and solar cells. Moreover, based on the current progress, we will also give some personal insights on the existing challenges and future research directions in this promising field.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The extensive consumption of non-renewable fossil fuels in the past decades has raised serious concerns about the sustainability of global energy supplies, along with their associated effects on the environment. Therefore, it is quite urgent and necessary to develop efficient methods to utilize the renewable energy sources, such as solar energy and wind power.[1] Alternatively, hydrogen energy is another promising energy source, which is clean, environmentally friendly, and in principle, inexhaustible.[2] Recently, it has been revealed that electrocatalytic hydrogen generation based on earth-abundant materials is a promising way to obtain hydrogen energy.[3]

Generally, the most widely studied MDCs, such as MoS2, WS2, MoSe2 and WSe2, crystallize in 2H phase, exhibiting semiconducting property with large bandgap. Although the semiconducting properties of these 2D MDCs render them promising candidates for electronics and optoelectronics, the low intrinsic electrical conductivity limits their application in energy storage/conversion, in which the conductivity is one of the key factors for achieving excellent performance. Promisingly, recent studies have demonstrated that the phase engineering of semiconducting 2H phase to metastable metallic 1T phase of some 2D MDCs (e.g., MoS2 and WS2) can remarkably boost their intrinsic conductivity, enabling them promising in some applications, such as electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution,[17] electrochemical supercapacitors[18] and low-resistance contact transistors.[19]
The extraordinary properties and various potential applications of 2D MDCs greatly stimulate the development of different kinds of methods for synthesis of 2D MDCs with varying size, thickness and chemical/electronic properties.[20] Until now, 2D MDCs with single- and few-layer thickness can be prepared by a number of ways, such as mechanical exfoliation, chemical vapor deposition (CVD), liquid exfoliation and chemical synthesis.[21] Among these methods, the solution-processed approaches, such as sonication-assisted exfoliation, Li-intercalation and exfoliation, electrochemical Li-intercalation and exfoliation, hydro/solvothermal synthesis and colloidal synthesis, are capable of producing solution-processed 2D MDCs in high yield and large scale, that are essential for energy storage/conversion applications in which large amounts of samples are required for the electrode and device fabrication.[20,22]
The sonication-assisted exfoliation method relies on the direct sonication of the layered bulk MDC crystals in solvents or polymer/surfactant solutions to weaken the van der Waals interaction between MDC layers and obtain dispersed 2D MDC nanosheets.[20,23] Although this simple method can produce 2D MDCs in large amounts, the yield of single-layer MDC nanosheets is relatively low (no more than a few tens of percentages) and the lateral size of produced nanosheets is relatively small. The chemical Li-intercalation method uses organolithium compounds, e.g., n-butyllithium (n-BuLi), as the intercalators to react with layered MDC bulk crystals to form Li-intercalated compounds, followed with a sonication in water to obtain dispersed 2D MDCs nanosheets.[21a,24] This method allows us to produce single-layer MDCs in high yield and large scale. However, the reaction normally requires long time (e.g., 3 days) and high temperature (e.g., 100 °C), and the organolithium compounds are highly sensitive to water and oxygen.
Alternatively, inspired by LIBs, our group developed an electrochemical Li-intercalation and exfoliation method for the efficient production of single-layer MDCs at room temperature within 1 day.[22a,25] The basic idea is to use layered bulk MDC crystal-coated metal foil as the cathode and Li foil as the anode to fabricate a battery cell, which was then undergone a discharge process to intercalate Li+ ions into layered MDC crystals to form Li-intercalated compounds. The hydro/solvothermal synthesis is based on the reactions of precursors that were dissolved in water or organic solvents and sealed in an autocalave under temperature normally less than 250 °C.[26] This method is able to produce 2D MDCs in high yield at relatively low cost. However, flower-like few-layer nanosheets are normally obtained rather than single-layer MDCs by using this method.
The colloidal synthesis relies on the reactions of precursors in oil phase at a certain temperature by using long-chain oleylamines and/or oleic acids as the surfactants.[22b,c] This method allows us to prepare 2D MDCs with controllable size and thickness. However, the residual long-chain surfactants on the prepared 2D MDCs are not favorable for the energy storage/conversion applications.
More importantly, the aforementioned solution-processed 2D MDCs can serve as promising templates or building blocks for the preparation of various 2D MDC-based composites to further enhance their physical and chemical properties and thus to achieve the improved performance in specific applications.[27]
Here, we focus on the discussion of solution-processed 2D MDCs and their functional composites for energy storage/conversion applications, including rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors, electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution and solar cells, with highlights on the advantages of solution-based synthetic approaches as well as 2D MDC-based nanomaterials with outstanding performance.

sections.heading: 2. Rechargeable Batteries
sections.text:
Rechargeable batteries, e.g., LIBs, are one of the most typical electrochemical energy storage devices that are able to reversibly convert chemical energy to electrical power.[28] Since the first demonstration of commercial LIBs by Sony in the 1990s, nowadays LIBs have been widely used in our daily life from portable electronic devices to electrical vehicles.[28a] However, a drastic increase in lithium demand and hence an impending supply shortage have led to an increasing cost of lithium resources, which restricts the extensive usage of LIBs in some large-scale energy storage applications such as electricity grid.[29] Therefore, it is quite urgent to develop other types of rechargeable batteries with low cost and high energy density. As a result, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs),[30] Mg batteries,[31] and lithiumsulfur (Li-S) batteries[32] have also been developed based on the recently emerged demands for large-scale power sources.[28c] The performance of all the rechargeable batteries strongly relies on the properties of the electrode materials.[28c,33] Fortunately, the intensive research on graphene in the past decade have provided many opportunities to develop graphene-based electrodes
for high-performance rechargeable batteries.[34] Since 2D MDCs having similar structural features with graphene and high theoretical capacities, they have also been considered as promising electrode materials for rechargeable batteries in recent years.[15e] In this section, we will review the recent development of rechargeable batteries based on 2D MDCs, with emphasize on the advantages of solution-processed 2D MDC-based nanomaterials with varied structures and compositions as well as their corresponding performances.

sections.heading: 2.1. Lithium-Ion Batteries (LIBs)
sections.text:
LIBs, one of the most attractive energy storage devices, have been widely utilized in our daily life.[28b,35] Due to the advantages of low cost, natural abundance, high Coulombic efficiency and flat potential profile during cycling process, graphite has been widely used as the anode material of commercial LIBs. Layered MDCs (e.g., MoS2 and WS2) with analogous structures to graphite, in which the weak van der Waals interactions among layers allow the intercalation of atoms/molecules into the interlayer space of MDCs, have been considered as alternative candidates for LIB anodes. Most of layered MDCs possess theoretical capacities higher than that of the traditional graphite anode (372 mAh/g), making them promising candidates as the electrode materials for LIBs.[36] For example, MoS2 has a high theoretical capacity of 670 mAh/g based on the 4-electrontransfer reaction (MoS2 + 4Li+ + 4e− ↔ Mo + 2Li2S) and thus has emerged as one of the promising anode materials in recent years.[37] However, the practical usage of MDCs in LIBs is still limited by their poor cycling properties and rate capabilities. Typically, bulk MoS2 shows a discharge capacity close to its theoretical capacity in the first charge/discharge cycle, while the rapid degradation of capacity, especially at high charge/ discharge rate, can be normally observed during the subsequent cycles (e.g., the capacity of bulk MoS2 decreased from ≈800 to ≈300 mAh/g in less than 20 cycles[12]). This is because most of the MDCs are intrinsically semiconducting, thus give relatively low electrical conductivity as compared to graphite, which severely limits the charge transfer process, leading to poor high-rate performance. In addition, the inevitable destruction of MDC structures and pulverization of electrode materials during the repetitive intercalation/deintercalation of lithium ions lead to a rapid decay of capacity.
Recently, 2D MDC-based LIB electrode materials have attracted increasing attention. The ultrathin thickness and high surface-to-volume ratio of 2D MDCs can provide abundant active sites, low intercalation barriers and short diffusion path for Li+ ions, thus making them attractive as electrode materials for LIBs.[15e,38] However, due to the high surface energy and van der Waals attraction, 2D MDCs are easily restacked to form layered configuration with similar structure to their bulk counterparts. This leads to the loss of extraordinary properties of 2D MDCs that arise from their unique 2D structures as well as the deterioration of their LIB performances. Therefore, novel strategies for the development of high-performance 2D MDC-based electrode materials are still highly desirable. To date, various 2D MDC-based electrode materials have been developed for LIBs, aiming to achieve enhanced specific capacity, high-rate property

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Electrodes Based on MDC Nanosheet-Assembled Hierarchical Structures
sections.text:
Assembling 2D MDC nanosheets into various hierarchical structures is a feasible way to fabricate high-performance electrode materials for LIBs. LIB electrodes based on hierarchical structures normally exhibit large contact areas between electrodes and electrolytes, allowing for the rapid diffusion of Li+ ions.[39c,40] Intriguingly, electrode materials with hollow structures can effectively accommodate the mechanical stress induced by lithium intercalation/de-intercalation and inhibit the pulverization problems of electrode materials, leading to enhanced cycling stabilities.[35a,39e,41] As a typical example, Low et al. synthesized hierarchical MoS2 microboxes with hollow structure assembled by ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets through a facile template-assisted strategy (Figure 1).[37b] Briefly, the MnCO3 microcube template was firstly synthesized through a simple co-precipitation method. MoS2 nanosheets were then grown onto the MnCO3 template via a hydrothermal reaction with the assistance of L-cysteine, during which MnCO3 was converted to MnS (Figure 1a). Finally, MoS2 microboxes assembled from nanosheets were obtained after removing the MnS template via acid etching with subsequent thermal annealing treatment (Figure 1b-e). The resultant hierarchical MoS2 structure was then used as electrode of LIBs, which showed a high reversible capacity of 900 mAh/g at a current density of 100 mA/g for 50 charge/discharge cycles (Figure 1f). Importantly, the MoS2 electrode still maintained a capacity of 700 mAh/g even at high current density of 1000 mA/g, indicating its good rate capability (Figure 1g). The enhanced lithium storage property of the MoS2 microbox should be attributed to the following reasons. First, the MoS2 microbox was constructed by ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets, which exhibited high surface area of 21 m2/g.[37b] Since the electrode material with such structure might have large interfacial lithium storage capacity, the MoS2 microbox showed an initial discharge capacity of ≈1100 mAh/g, exceeding the theoretical capacity of MoS2. Second, the hierarchically hollow structure of MoS2 microbox not only enabled easy access of Li+ ions to the surface of MoS2 nanosheets, but also effectively accommodated the volume change of MoS2 during the charge/discharge process, leading to the better cycling stability and rate capability as compared to the MoS2 microparticle counterpart (Figure 1f,g).
Moreover, hierarchical MoS2 spheres assembled from ultrathin MoS2 sheets have also been synthesized through a hydrothermal method followed by a thermal annealing process, which were then used as electrode materials for LIBs.[40a] The as-prepared anode material delivered reversible specific capacities of 880 and 676 mAh/g after 50 charge/discharge cycles at 100 and 1000 mA/g, respectively. The good electrochemical stability of this kind of MoS2 electrode is partially attributed to the three-dimensional (3D) hierarchical structure, which facilitates
the penetration of electrolyte and reduces the mechanical strain induced by insertion/extraction of lithium ions, leading to superior Li storage properties. Notably, the carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC), instead of the commonly used polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), was used as the binder for the fabrication of MoS2 electrode.[40a] It is believed that the strong interaction between CMC and MoS2 can effectively preserve the structural stability of the electrode material, giving rise to the enhanced electrochemical stability during cycling.
Similarly, hierarchical structures with different morphologies assembled from other 2D MDC nanosheets, such as SnS2,[39b,d,42] WS2[43] and CoS2[40b] have also been synthesized as electrodes for LIBs. In addition, hierarchical MDC structures also can be obtained by the direct growth of 2D MDCs on current collectors, which can be directly used as the electrodes without additional polymer binders. As a typical example, vertically aligned SnS2 nanosheets were directly synthesized on the Sn foil, where the Sn substrate acted as both tin precursor and metallic current collector.[44]
2D MDC nanosheet-assembled hierarchical structures possess the advantage of large exposed active surface area and fast ion diffusion rate, leading to the improved LIB performance including high-rate capability and cycling stability as compared to their bulk counterparts. The recent development of various synthetic strategies also enables the preparation of hierarchically structured 2D MDC materials with varied morphologies, microstructures and porosities for LIBs. However, it should be pointed out that the preparation of those hierarchical structures is normally complicated and involves multiple steps. For practical applications, it might be challenging to extend the production from lab scale to industry scale, meanwhile, preserve the uniformity and reproducibility of their microstructures and morphologies. In addition, the density of these hierarchically structured materials is typically low, especially for those with hollow structures, resulting in a low volumetric energy density. This might be another concern for using these kinds of electrode materials for practical applications.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Electrodes Based on 2D MDCs with Expanded Interlayer Distance
sections.text:
Besides the construction of hierarchical structures, enlarging the interlayer distance of 2D MDCs to prepare expanded 2D MDCs is another attractive strategy to optimize their LIB performance. Theoretically speaking, expanded 2D MDCs can effectively reduce the energy barrier of lithium intercalation and largely accommodate the volume change of electrode materials during the charge/discharge process, thus achieving high lithium storage capacity and long cycling stability.[45] For instance, restacked MoS2 nanosheets with expanded interlayer spacing can be prepared by restacking the chemically exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets produced by exfoliation of the bulk MoS2 crystal using n-BuLi as the exfoliation agent, in which the interlayer spacing of MoS2 was increased from 0.620 nm to 0.635 nm.[12] The restacked MoS2 nanosheets showed specific surface area of 9.83 m2/g, ≈2 times of that of the bulk MoS2 (4.89 m2/g). As expected, the LIB electrode based on the restacked MoS2 nanosheets exhibited a reversible capacity of ≈750 mAh/g after

Similarly, restacked WS2 nanosheets have also been prepared as electrode for LIBs with enhanced capacity and cycling performance.[46] Although the exfoliated MDC nanosheets have exhibited superior LIB performance compared to their bulk counterparts, the practical and large-scale application of exfoliated MDC nanosheets is still limited. For example, for the chemical Li-intercalation and exfoliation method, a large amount of unsafe organics (e.g., n-BuLi) need to be utilized. For the sonication-assisted exfoliation method, the long-time ultrasonication will creat more defects on MDC nanosheets and thus reduce their conductivity.
Besides exfoliation, the hydrothermal method, a simple and easily scalable approach, has also been used to prepare 2D MDCs with expended interlayer distance for LIBs.[37b,47] As a typical example, MoS2 nanoplates with an enlarged interlayer distance of 0.69 nm and thickness of ≈30 nm were prepared by an onepot hydrothermal reaction using Mo(CO)6 and sulfur powder as precursors.[47b] Impressively, the LIB electrode based on the
expanded MoS2 nanoplates demonstrated an excellent rate capability, which delivered a reversible capacity of 700 mAh/g even at ultrahigh charge current density of 53.1 A/g (Figure 2a,b). In contrast, the capacity of the bulk MoS2 electrode quickly decreased to less than 200 mAh/g. Moreover, a full cell was also designed by using the prepared MoS2 nanoplates and LiCoO2 as the anode and cathode, respectively. The fabricated cell exhibited an initial capacity of 114 mAh/g and high capacity retention of 89% after 60 charge/discharge cycles (Figure 2c,d). In addition, the expanded 2D MDCs can also be prepared by inserting polyethylene oxide (PEO) molecules into the interlayer spacing of layered MDCs. The electrode based on the PEO-intercalated MoS2 nanosheets delivered a reversible capacity of ≈900 mAh/g at current density of 50 mA/g after 50 cycles.[48]

Moreover, due to the relatively low conductivity of 2D MDCs, highly conductive additives (e.g., acetylene blacks) are necessary to improve the conductivity of fabricated electrodes. The incorporation of 2D MDCs with other highly conductive materials to form composite electrodes has been demonstrated to be an attractive strategy to overcome these drawbacks of 2D MDCs, e.g., relatively low conductivity and easy restacking.[49] In general, these 2D MDC-based composite materials can be classified into four categories: 2D MDC-amorphous carbon composites, 2D MDCgraphene composites, MDC nanosheet-1D nanomaterial composites and MDC nanosheet-templated composites.
2.1.3.1. 2D MDC-Amorphous Carbon Composites: Carbonaceous materials (e.g., amorphous carbon) are one of the mostly used conductive matrices to composite with 2D MDCs and then used as electrodes for LIBs.[28e,50] As a typical example, amorphous carbon was employed to hybridize with MoS2 nanosheets to form a composite electrode, which exhibited a high reversible capacity of 912 mAh/g at 100 mA/g after 100 cycles.[51] In addition, the conductive carbon component can also improve the high-rate performance of composite electrodes. For example, Cao and co-workers reported that the amorphous carbon-coated MoS2 nanosheets showed a reversible capacity up to 672 mAh/g even at high current density of 10 A/g with nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency.[52] The 2D MDC-amorphous carbon composites prepared by hydrothermal methods are normally composed of MDC nanoflakes with low crystallinity, small grain size and thin thickness, which possess abundant defect sites and void
spaces within the composites. This facilitates the mass transport of electrolyte within the composite electrode and allows the intercalation of Li+ ions into 2D MDCs, thus contributing to the high reversible capacities and high-rate performances of those composite electrodes. It should be pointed out that the weight ratio of amorphous carbon to 2D MDCs in those composite electrodes also plays an important role in the LIB performances. Excessive carbon used in the preparation of 2D MDC-amorphous carbon composites may lead to the agglomeration of 2D MDCs and formation of thick carbon layers coated on 2D MDCs, which would block the diffusion pathways of Li+ ions and also increase the inactive mass proportion in the composite electrodes, leading to decreased specific capacity and cycling properties. Therefore, optimization of carbon content in 2D MDC-amorphous carbon composites is necessary to achieve both high-lithium storage capacity and good electrochemical stability for composite electrodes.

Besides MoS2, some other 2D MDCs including WS2,[43b,53f,55] MoSe2[49e,56] and SnS2,[57] have also been hybridized with graphene and then used as electrode materials for LIBs. Obviously, the incorporation of graphene can not only give rise to the significantly enhanced specific capacity, but also enhance
the cycling stability and high-rate capability of the composite electrodes, as compared to their corresponding pure 2D MDC counterparts. It is generally believed that the enhanced LIB performance of 2D MDC-graphene composites is attributed to the synergistic effect between 2D MDCs and graphene. First, the aggregation of MDC nanosheets can be inhibited in the composites, resulting in 2D MDCs with thinner thickness and/or smaller size. Second, the high electrical conductivity of graphene can facilitate the rapid electron transport during the electrochemical reaction in the composite electrode. Third, the interconnected graphene sheets form a 3D network, which can also serve as elastic matrix to suppress the pulverization of electrode materials, leading to a stable cycling performance.
Moreover, 2D MDCs have also been grown on 3D graphene aerogels or networks to form 3D composite electrodes for LIBs.[35b,58] For example, Shen and co-workers reported the growth of honeycomb-like MoS2 structures on CVD-grown 3D graphene networks (HC-MoS2@GF) by a polymer-assisted solution-phase method (Figure 3).[58b] The resultant electrode demonstrated a reversible capacity of 1100 mAh/g at current density of 200 mA/g, surpassing both of electrodes made of the MoS2 hollow spheres hybridized with and without 3D graphene networks (Figure 3c). Remarkably, even cycling at high current density of 5000 mA/g, a reversible capacity of ≈800 mAh/g can be maintained for the HC-MoS2@GF composite electrode (Figure 3d). One of the advantages of the HC-MoS2@GF composite is that they can be directly used as the electrode for LIBs. sections.text:
addition, composites constructed with 2D MDCs and onedimensional (1D) nanomaterials, such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs),[49b,59] carbon fibers,[60] metal oxide tubes/wires[61] and polymer wires,[62] have also been developed as electrodes for LIBs. For example, Yang and co-workers prepared the MoSx (2<x<3) sheet-coated CNTs by a solvothermal method for LIBs.[63] A reversible capacity of ≈1000 mAh/g was achieved at current density of 50 mA/g, which is much higher than that of pure MWNTs (≈250 mAh/g at 50 mA/g) and the theoretical capacity of MoS2 (670 mAh/g).[37] Similarly, several other reports have also demonstrated the fabrication of CNT-2D MDC composites, including CNT-SnS2[50b] and CNT-WS2,[64] for LIBs with improved capacities and/or cycling stabilities.
Recently, Yu and co-workers reported that the growth of MoS2 nanosheets on carbon nanofibers (CNFs) is also a feasible approach to fabricate anode materials of LIBs with enhanced performance.[60b] Briefly, CNFs were first prepared by using Te nanowires as the sacrificed template. The MoS2 nanosheets were then grown on the surface of CNFs using a hydrothermal method to form MoS2-CNF composite. Such composite electrode showed a remarkably high capacity of 1264 mAh/g after charge/discharge for 50 cycles at current density of 100 mA/g. In contrast, the electrodes of bare CNFs and MoS2 only delivered capacities of 390 and 124 mAh/g, respectively. Impressively, a high capacity of 688 mAh/g still remained after the charge/discharge process for 300 cycles at 1000 mA/g, which is higher than the theoretical capacity of MoS2 (670 mAh/g). Moreover, the good LIB performance of the MoS2-CNF composite electrode could be ascribed to the synergistic effect between MoS2 nanosheets and CNFs, which arises from the high electrical conductivity of CNFs and the unique hierarchical nanostructure of MoS2-CNF composites. First, the CNFs can form a conductive network in electrode that provides an efficient electron pathway for a rapid charge transfer process. The rigid structure of CNFs also prevents the aggregation of MoS2CNF composites and improves their electrochemical stability. Second, the MoS2 nanosheets anchored on the CNFs possess abundant exposed electrochemical active sites, which facilitate the migration of Li+ ions and effectively accommodate the volume change of MoS2 during the lithiation/delithiation process. Third, it was found that the transformation from MoS2 to MoS3 occurred during the charging process of the MoS2CNF composite electrode.[60b] MoS3 features larger capacity and better cyclability as compared to MoS2, which gradually became the main active component of the composite during cycling and played an important role in the increased capacity of the composite electrode. Forth, the interfacial Li-ion storage may also contribute to the high capacity of the composite electrode, which has a porous nanostructure and large surface area.
2.1.3.4. MDC Nanosheet-Templated Composites: Owing to the large lateral size and high surface area, 2D MDC nanosheets could also be used as promising templates for the growth of many other materials, including Fe3O4 nanoparticles (NPs),[27d,65]
Ag NPs[66], ceramics[67] and conductive polymers,[68] which were then used as electrodes for LIBs. For example, the composite of Fe3O4 NP-decorated MoS2 nanosheets prepared by a twostep hydrothermal reaction delivered capacities of 1033 and 224 mAh/g at current densities of 2 and 10 A/g, respectively.[27d]

sections.heading: 2.2. Sodium-Ion Batteries (SIBs)
sections.text: As an alternative to LIBs, SIBs have received substantial attention recently.[29,69] Compared with lithium, the abundant resource of sodium makes SIBs cost-effective, which are potentially competitive with LIBs in large-scale energy storage system such as electricity grid.[70] The well-developed technology on LIBs over the past decades, especially numerous available methods for the preparation of electrode materials with various nanostructures, also promotes the development of SIBs in recent years.[29,30] However, sodium ion is much larger than lithium ion (0.106 nm vs 0.076 nm in ionic radius),[71] resulting in a slow electrochemical reaction kinetics along with a large volume variation of electrode materials during the charge/discharge process.[72] Owing to the large interlayer spacing, layered MDCs have been proven to be promising electrode materials for SIBs, which can facilitate the fast and reversible intercalation and de-intercalation of sodium ions.[70,73] Until now, 2D MDC-based nanomaterials have been widely explored as electrode materials for SIBs. In this section, we will focus on the discussion of electrode materials based on the solution-processed 2D MDCs and their composites for SIBs.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Electrodes Based on Pure 2D MDCs
sections.text:
A number of 2D MDCs including MoS2 (theoretical capacity of 668 mAh/g based on the conversion reactions[74]) have been developed as electrode materials for SIBs,[72,75] which are summarized in Table 1. For example, the exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets delivered reversible capacities of 386 and 251 mAh/g at current densities of 40 and 320 mA/g after 100 cycles, respectively.[72] Similar to LIBs, 2D MDCs with enlarged interlayer distance have been proved to be promising candidates as electrode materials for SIBs, in which the fast reaction kinetics can be achieved due to the easier intercalation of Na+ ions into the enlarged interlayer spacing of 2D MDCs. For instance, MoS2 nanoflowers with different interlayer distance ranging from 0.63 to 0.69 nm were prepared for SIBs (Figure 4a-c).[75b] The resultant electrode based on MoS2 flakes with the largest interlayer distance (FGMoS2) exhibited the highest capacity and best rate capability (Figure 4d,e). Moreover, the as-prepared FG-MoS2 electrode also showed good cycling stability for 1500 cycles with reversible capacities of 300 and 195 mAh/g at 1 and 10 A/g, respectively (Figure 4f). Interestingly, the capacities kept increasing during continuous charge/discharge cycles for the MoS2 electrodes measured at different current densities, which is especially obvious for the one tested at 0.05 A/g (Figure 4f). This phenomenon indicates that the interlayer spacing of MoS2 was gradually expanded during cycling, and thus more active sites for electrochemical reaction generated and the energy barrier for the intercalation/de-intercalation of Na+ ions was decreased

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Electrodes Based on 2D MDC-Based Composites
sections.text:
Previous studies have revealed the enhanced performance of LIBs can be achieved using composite electrodes obtained by hybridizing 2D MDCs with carbonaceous materials.[15e,54,77]
Similarly, this strategy is also applicable to SIBs. So far, composites consisting of 2D MDCs and amorphous carbon,[78] fibers,[27b,69a,79] or CNTs[75a] have been developed as electrodes for SIBs. The SIB performance of these composite electrodes is summarized in Table 1. It clearly shows that improved specific capacity and/or cycling stability have been achieved for composite electrodes compared to their individual counterparts. For example, a reversible capacity of 520 mAh/g at current density of 67 mA/g after 50 cycles was achieved on the electrode based on amorphous carbon-coated MoS2 nanosheets synthesized by a hydrothermal method.[78] Even at high current density of 670 mA/g, a capacity of 400 mAh/g still remained for this composite electrode after 300 charge/discharge cycles.
Composite electrodes composing of graphene and 2D MDCs have also been developed for SIBs. MDC nanosheets possess the similar 2D structure with graphene, which enable a close contact with surface-to-surface feature at the interface between graphene and MDC nanosheets. This is distinct from the interface between MDC nanosheets and 0D/1D materials, where a point-to-point or line-to-line contact is presented. In addition, due to the tunable Fermi level of graphene, small Schottky barrier can form in the 2D heterojunction of graphene and MDC nanosheets, facilitating the electron transfer between them.[80] Therefore, the graphene-2D MDC composites have been one of the most promising electrode materials for SIBs.[76a,81] For example, Wang and co-worker investigated the adsorption and diffusion properties of sodium ions at the heterointerface of rGO-MoS2 composite by first-principles calculations.[81a] This

Although the formation of SEI results in an irreversible capacity loss during the initial charge cycle, a stable SEI layer can stabilize the reactive interface between the active electrode and the liquid electrolyte, which prevents the further side reactions between them.[78] Therefore, the performance of battery, such as columbic efficiency, reversibility and rate capability, can be optimized by controlling the formation of SEI layer.[73a,74a] As the first example, Hu et al. performed an in situ atomic force microscopy (AFM) measurement to investigate the formation process of SEI layer in the electrode of exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets during the charge/discharge process of SIBs.[83] The experiment was conducted in a planar microscale battery (Figure 5b), which enabled the in situ measurement of topographical variation (e.g., surface roughness) as well as force spectroscopy studies of the MoS2 electrode during cycling. It was found that a SEI film with thickness of 20.4 ± 10.9 nm was formed on both edges and basel planes of MoS2 flakes at discharge voltage of ≈1.5 V, along with a permanent structural wrinkling of the MoS2 flakes. Recently, Chou et al. reported a thin and stable SEI layer can be induced by adding 5 wt% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) into the commonly used electrolyte for SIBs, i.e., a NaClO4 solution dissolved in propylene carbonate (PC) and ethylene carbonate (EC).[74b] As compared to other electrolytes, the MoS2-amorphose carbon composite electrode that measured in the electrolyte with FEC additive exhibited better cycling performance and rate capability (Figure 5c,d).

sections.heading: 2.3. Other Types of Batteries
sections.text:
In addition to the aforementioned LIBs and SIBs, 2D MDCbased materials have also been employed in other types of rechargeable batteries, such as rechargeable Mg batteries[84] and lithium-sulphur (Li-S) batteries.[3a,85]
Rechargeable Mg batteries have exhibited great potential for reversible electrochemical energy storage and conversion, due to the high theoretical specific capacity of Mg anode (2205 mAh/g) and the natural abundance of Mg raw material.[86] 2D MDCs and their composites have been investigated as the cathode materials for rechargeable Mg batteries.[84b–d] As a typical example, Chen et al. reported the fabrication of rechargeable Mg batteries by using the MoS2 flakes synthesized through hydrothermal method and Mg NPs as cathode and anode, respectively. The resultant Mg battery exhibited a reversible discharge capacity of 170 mAh/g at current density of 20 mA/g.[84c] In contrast, the battery fabricated based on bulk MoS2 and bulk Mg delivered a much lower capacity of only 35 mAh/g. The enhanced capacity of MoS2 flake-based battery should be attributed to the high activity of Mg nanoparticle with small size (≈2.5 nm) as well as the enlarged interlayer distance of MoS2 flakes (0.65-0.70 nm), which allow an easy access of Mg2+ ions to MoS2 surface. Moreover, the MoS2-PEO composite
has also been prepared for Mg batteries recently.[84b] Specifically, the presence of PEO inhibited the close packing of MoS2 nanosheets, resulting in an increased interlayer distance up to 1.45 nm. A reversible capacity of ≈75 mAh/g was achieved on the composite electrode, which is ≈3.4 times of that on the bulk MoS2 electrode. It is noted that PEO is electrochemically inert and ionically conducting, which neither alters the intrinsic electrochemical properties of MoS2 nor blocks the diffusion path of Mg2+ ions. Therefore, the aforementioned approach for fabricating MoS2-PEO composite electrode for Mg batteries[84b] might be also applicable to other 2D MDCs.
Li-S batteries have been recognized as promising energy storage devices due to their high theoretical energy density of 2600 Wh/kg and low cost.[87] Layered MDCs have also been applied for Li-S batteries.[3a,85] It has been demonstrated that layered MDCs, e.g., FeS2 and MoS2, can be converted into Li2S and metallic Fe or Mo during the full discharge process of LIBs and the resultant Li2S-metal composites can act as potential cathode materials for Li-S batteries.[85a,87]
Recently, 2D MDCs have been reported as encapsulation materials for Li2S cathodes, which effectively inhibited the dissolution of intermediate lithium polysulfides (Li2Sn, n = 4–8) formed in the charge/discharge process and thus improved the cycling performance of Li-S batteries.[85c] As a typical example, the TiS2 sheet-coated Li2S particles with a core-shell nanostructure (Li2S@TiS2) have been prepared as the cathode material for Li-S batteries (Figure 6).[85c] The synthetic approach is schematically shown in Figure 6a. sections.heading: 3. Supercapacitors
sections.text:
As a promising alternative to batteries, supercapacitors have been generally considered as one of the most ideal candidates for green energy storage, because of the advantages of ultrahigh power density, long cycling life, low cost of maintenance and safe operation.[88] Based on the charge storage mechanism of supercapacitors, electrode materials exhibit different electrochemical behaviors.[89] Porous carbons are the typical electrode materials for electrical double layer capacitors (EDLCs), one of the most typical supercapacitors, which store charges by accumulating ions at the interface between electrode and electrolyte and have limited energy density.[90] The electrode materials of pseudocapacitors, such as RuO2 and MnO2, exhibit a liner dependence of the stored charge with varying potential within the potential window, which is similar to that of EDLCs but based on different electron-transfer mechanisms.[91] For MDCbased electrode materials, the faradic redox reaction can occur on the transition metal centers of some MDCs, which contributes to the surface redox capacitance.[15c,92] Taking MoS2 as an example, the Mo ion exhibits a range of oxidation states from Mo2+ to Mo6+.[93] The redox peaks were clearly observed on the MoS2 electrode tested in various aqueous electrolytes including KOH, H2SO4 and Na2SO4, indicating its Faradaic chargestorage behavior.[93]
2D MDCs not only can facilitate the access of electrolyte ions, such as H+, Li+ and Na+, to their surfaces, but also can offer large active sites for redox reactions, which are expected to exhibit better supercapacitor performance as compared to their bulk counterparts.[94] For example, the MoS2 nanosheets which were obtained by the liquid-phase exfoliation of bulk MoS2 powder in 1-dodecyl-2-pyrrolidinone exhibited capacitance of 2 mF/cm2 in the electrolyte of 6 mol/L KOH aqueous solution, which is much higher than that of the bulk MoS2 (0.5 mF/cm2).[95] Up to now, a number of 2D MDC-based electrode materials have been developed for supercapacitors, which are summarized in Table 2. However, the specific capacitance
of pure 2D MoS2 nanosheets is still low (Table 2), which might be due to its poor conductivity.[96]
Recently, Chhowalla and co-workers demonstrated that the metallic 1T phase of MoS2 (1T-MoS2) nanosheet is a promising electrode material for supercapacitors (Figure 7).[18] The high conductivity of 1T-MoS2 ensures a fast electron transfer rate, leading to enhanced supercapacitor performance. Monolayered MoS2 nanosheets with high concentration of metallic 1T phase (≈70%) were prepared by the lithium intercalation and exfoliation method using n-BuLi as the exfoliation agent.[18] The freestanding 1T-MoS2 thin film was then fabricated from the exfoliated 1T-MoS2 nanosheets by a simple vacuum filtration method, which was then used as electrode for supercapacitors. Note that the 2H-MoS2 thin film electrode can be obtained by simply annealing the as-prepared 1T-MoS2 electrode at 300°C under Ar. As shown in Figure 7a,b, different electrolytes including aqueous and organic solutions were employed to examine the supercapacitor performance of the 1T-MoS2 electrode. Obviously, the capacitance of 1T-MoS2 electrode is much larger than that of 2H-MoS2 electrode (Figure 7a). It was found that the highest capacitance of 650 F/cm2 was achieved in H2SO4 aqueous electrolyte at scan rate of 20 mV/s. Impressively, all measured electrodes exhibited capacitance retention over 90% after 5000 charge/discharge cycles at a current density of 2 A/g (Figure 7c). In addition, the electrode of 1T-MoS2 nanosheets exhibited remarkably high volumetric energy and power densities as shown in the Ragone plot, for example, 0.11 Wh/cm3 at 1.1 W/cm3, which surpassed many other reported electrode materials (Figure 7d). The outstanding electrochemical properties of 1T-MoS2 nanosheets can be attributed to the following reasons. First, the conductivity of 1T-MoS2 (10–100 S/cm) is ≈107 times higher than that of 2H-MoS2, which is also comparable with that of rGO.[18] The high conductivity of 1T-MoS2 ensures a fast electron transfer rate, leading to enhanced supercapacitor performance. Second, the hydrophilic (contact angle of 28°) and negatively charged 1T-MoS2 nanosheets (surface potential ranging from −40 to −50 mV),[18] which is arising from the charge transfer from butyl group of n-BuLi to 1T-MoS2 nanosheets, enable a good wettability of 1T-MoS2 electrode in various aqueous electrolytes and facilitate the rapid cation-intercalation process. Third, the 1T-MoS2 electrodes were fabricated by the restacking of nanosheets, which have larger interlayer spacing than does bulk MoS2, facilitating the intercalation of various electrolyte ions. This can be also indicated by the broadened (002) peaks and the increased intensities of (001) peaks in the XRD spectra of 1T-MoS2 electrodes after the intercalation

Second, the assembled hierarchical structure of hollow spheres can reduce the diffusion path length of electrolyte ions, leading to a good rate capability.

sections.heading: 4. Flexible Electrochemical Energy Storage Devices
sections.text:
High-performance flexible energy storage devices are highly desirable for the next-generation electronic devices, e.g., rollup displays, e-paper, wearable electronics.[109] In the past decade, graphene has been demonstrated as one of the most promising electrode materials for constructing flexible power sources, owing to its unique chemical, electronic and mechanical properties.[7a,110] As an analogue of graphene, 2D MDCs, possessing the similar advantages, including ultrathin structure and flexibility as well as a large number of members with varied compositions, could also be alternative candidates as electrode materials for the fabrication of high-performance flexible energy storage devices.[111]
The development of high-performance electrode materials with good mechanical strength is of great importance for flexible energy storage devices. So far, a number of 2D MDC-based materials with good flexibility, including films and fibers, have been demonstrated as promising flexible electrodes (Figure 9).[18,98,111b,112] Typically, flexible films composed of 2D MDC nanosheets can be easily fabricated by the simple vacuum filtration method, in which the thickness and composition of films can be easily tuned.[18,98] The van der Waals interaction between 2D MDC nanosheets ensured the mechanical stability of the fabricated films and enabled the direct use of the films as electrodes without additional polymer binders. The mechanical strength of 2D MDC films can be further enhanced by the combination of MDC sheets with graphene[55,76a,111b,d,113] or CNTs.[59a,64] For instance, Singh et al. fabricated the rGO-MoS2 composite film as the electrode for SIBs, which exhibited a tensile strength of 9.48 MPa with failure strain of ≈2.2 %.[76a] It is noteworthy that the carbon additives not only contribute to the enhanced structural stability of the composite films, but also serve as the elastic matrices accommodating the mechanical strains of resultant composite electrodes during the cycling process.
Recently, fiber-based devices have attracted increasing attentions due to the mature textile technology nowadays, which might have great potential application in wearable and portable electronics.[114] The composite fibers composing of 2D MDCs and carbon materials exhibited excellent flexibility, good mechanical strength, high electrical conductivity and light weight and thus are promising candidates for flexible energy storage devices.[60a,b] As a typical example, recently, we developed a flexible supercapacitor device based on the composite fibers composing of MoS2, rGO and MWCNTs (Figure 9d and 10).[112b] The fabricated composite fibers can be tightly knotted, exhibiting good flexibility (Figure 9d). The flexible supercapacitor device was fabricated by placing two different composite fibers, i.e., MoS2-rGO/MWCNT and rGO/MWCNT fibers, in parallel on the flexible polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrate with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)-H2SO4 gel as electrolyte (Figure 10a). The resultant device delivered a specific capacitance of 5.2 F/cm3 at current density of 0.16 A/cm3. This flexible supercapacitor device also showed stable electrochemical performance without obvious fading of its capacitance under bending status (Figure 10b,c), indicating the potential application in flexible energy storage devices.
Besides the 2D MDC-based flexible films and fibers, 2D MDCs have also been deposited onto other substrates with high mechanical strength and flexibility, which can be directly used as flexible electrodes.[111c,112a,115] As known, the commercially available carbon cloth is one of the most commonly used flexible substrates with high strength, electrical conductivity, and resistance to corrosion.[116] Recently, the MoS2 nanoflake-coated carbon cloth has been fabricated by a hydrothermal method and then used as the flexible anode in LIBs.[111c] This composite electrode possesses a tensile strength of 3.7 Mpa and can be rolled up at an arbitrary angle, indicating its high flexibility. A full cell was fabricated by using the composite electrode and a commercial LiCoO2/Al foil as the anode and cathode, respectively. The initial discharge capacity of the full cell is about 1.41 mAh/cm2 (Figure 10d). Surprisingly, this full cell can still light a red light-emitting diode (LED) even after 50 cycles of bending (inset of Figure 10d).

sections.heading: 5. Electrocatalytic Hydrogen Generation
sections.text:
Hydrogen is considered to be a promising sustainable clean energy in the foreseeable future, and can be produced from
water through different ways such as photolysis, thermochemical cycles, and electrolysis.[117] Among these methods, electrochemical splitting of water into hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2) is one of the most efficient processes.[2a] The electrocatalyst, which reduces the overpotential and increases the efficiency of the electrochemical process, plays a key role in the electrochemical hydrogen evolution reaction (HER).[118] Generally, an efficient HER electrocatalyst should possess a small overpotential, high current density and excellent stability as well as low cost in fabrication.[119] Currently, the state-of-art HER electrocatalysts greatly rely on the Pt-based catalysts.[120] However, they suffer from the drawbacks of high cost and scarcity of Pt. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop alternative HER electrocatalysts based on earth-abundant materials. Recent studies have demonstrated that 2D MDC-based nanomaterials, especially MoS2 and WS2 nanosheets, could be promising non-precious alternatives for the electrocatalytic HER.[25a,121] In this section, we will focus on the introduction of 2D MDC-based nanomaterials as electrocatalysts towards HER with emphasis on those materials with excellent performance.

sections.heading: 5.1. Rational Design of 2D MDC-Based Electrocatalysts
sections.text:
The electrocatalytic HER property of bulk MoS2 has been studied since 1970s.[2a,122] However, the bulk MoS2 exhibited much lower catalytic activity with a Tafel slop of 692 mV/dec and an onset potential of -0.09 V as compared to Pt (30 mV/ dec and -0.02 V).[122a] In 2005, Nørskov et al. revealed that the free energy of hydrogen adsorption on MoS2 edge sites is close to that on hydrogenase and Pt,[123] indicating the edge site of MoS2 is highly active for HER. Later in 2007, Chorkendorff et al. experimentally demonstrated that the electrocatalytic activity of MoS2 for HER is greatly associated with the density of its edge site.[124] In this work, MoS2 NPs were synthesized on Au(111) substrate through physical vapor deposition, which exhibited a Tafel slope of 55–60 mV/dec and an onset potential of −0.15 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE).
Inspired by the aforementioned studies, great efforts have been devoted to exploring the nanostructured MoS2-based materials for hydrogen generation in recent years. In comparison with bulk MoS2, the nanostructured MoS2 possesses larger specific surface area and much more active sites, which is beneficial to the electrocatalytic process. In particular, the edge sites of MoS2, especially the sulfide-terminated Mo edges, are responsible for the catalytic activity.[10b,124] Therefore, preparation of nanostructured MoS2 with high-density edge sites, especially the sulfide-terminated Mo edges, is expected to improve the HER activity. For example, Dai et al. prepared a rGO-MoS2 NP hybrid through a one-step solvothermal reaction, which was then used for HER catalyst.[125] The rGO-MoS2 NP hybrids exhibited a small Tafel slope of ≈41 mV/decade and a overpotential of around −0.1 V.
Recently, single- and few-layer MoS2 nanosheets have been proven to be promising for HER. It is known that the resistivity of MoS2 along its basal plane is 2200 times lower than that across MoS2 layers.[126] The electron transfer within MoS2 particles needs to go through several layer interfaces, i.e., from the bottom layer of a MoS2 particle to its top layer, which severely

sections.heading: 5.2. Electrocatalysts Based on Pure 2D MDC Nanosheets
sections.text:
Generally, 2D MDC nanosheets (e.g., MoS2, WS2 and MoSe2) have a 2H phase with inherent semiconducting property and thus they normally show poor electrocatalytic activity for HER.[16,118] Two key factors, i.e., effective active sites and conductivity, can significantly affect the catalytic performance of a catalyst.[128] As known, the better conductivity and more active sites give raise to higher catalytic activity. Bearing this in mind, different strategies have been developed to prepare 2D MDCs with increased active sites and enhanced conductivity, in order to improve their catalytic performance. For example, Maschmeyer et al. reported the preparation of MoS2 nanosheets with abundant edges in anionic liquid (IL), which demonstrated enhanced catalytic performance toward HER.[129] In a typical experiment, the MoS2 nanosheets were synthesized by thermal decomposition of (NH4)2MoS4 in ionic liquid, which acts as not only a solvent for the synthesis of MoS2, but also an agent for
stabilizing the thermodynamically disfavored edge sites. The synthesized edge-rich MoS2 nanosheets exhibited higher HER catalytic activity as compared to its bulk counterpart. In another example, Xie et al. employed a scalable hydrothermal method to prepare defect-rich MoS2 nanosheets.[2b] The rich defects in MoS2 basal plane led to significant increase in active edges and surface area by forming cracks on the sheets. Compared to the defect-free MoS2 nanosheets, the MoS2 ultrathin nanosheets with abundant defect sites exhibited much enhanced HER performance with a small onset potential of –120 mV and Tafel slope of 50 mV/dec, as well as superior electrochemical cycling stability. Later on, the same group demonstrated that the enhanced electrocatalytic activity can also be achieved by incorporation of hetero-atoms in MoS2 nanosheets.[3b] It was found that the introduction of oxygen into MoS2 nanosheets effectively regulated the electronic structure and improved the intrinsic conductivity of MoS2 nanosheets. The resultant oxygen-incorporated MoS2 nanosheets exhibited superior HER performance with a small onset potential of −120 mV and Tafel slope of 55 mV/dec, and a good long-term stability. Similarly, Yan et al. presented that the S doping in MoSe2 nanosheets can also improve the intrinsic electrical conductivity of MoSe2 and thus lead to enhanced catalytic activity for HER.[130]
As known, MDCs have three main crystal phases, i.e., 1T, 2H and 3R.[118,131] Due to the high electrical conductivity, 2D MDC nanosheets with metallic 1T phase exhibit much enhanced HER performance compared to those with 2H phase.[16,19a,131] As a typical example, Chhowalla et al. demonstrated that the chemically exfoliated 1T-WS2 nanosheets exhibited high efficiency toward HER with low overpotential (Figure 11a,b).[17a] The

sections.heading: 6. Solar Energy Conversion Devices
sections.text:
Solar energy has been regarded as the most sustainable and renewable energy source, which is a great option to combat the current energy crisis including the rapid growth of energy usage and fast depletion of conventional fossil fuels.[1c] The conversion of sunlight into electricity or chemical fuels by solar cells or photoelectrochemical (PEC) cells has attracted increasing attention over the past decades.[1d,135] As one of the most studied 2D nanomaterials, graphene possesses high electrical conductivity and optical transparency, which can be readily integrated into photovoltaic devices to harness the solar energy.[136] However, its lack of intrinsic band gap has resulted in broad search for the other 2D semiconducting nanomaterials.[1a]
Recently, some intrinsic semiconducting MDCs have shown great potential in the solar energy conversion.[137] In particular, layered MDCs, such as MoS2, WS2, MoSe2 and WSe2, are potential candidates for the opto-electronic devices application
because of their suitable band gaps for the light absorption of solar spectrum.[138] Typically, the Schottky barrier solar cell based on the aluminum-coated p-type WSe2 single crystal yielded a decent efficiency about 5.3%.[139] In recent years, the successful preparation of single- or few-layer MDC nanosheets paves a new way for their applications in solar energy conversion devices, because of their layer-number-dependent physiochemical properties as discussed in the introduction section. The big difference in electronic structures and optical properties between single-/few-layer MDCs and their bulk counterparts makes 2D MDCs promising for photovoltaic devices. Importantly, theoretical calculations indicate 5–10% incident sunlight can be absorbed by monolayer MDCs, which is comparable to the light absorption property of Si film with thickness of 50 nm.[140] Moreover, due to the unique light absorption property, stacking of different 2D MDCs may be also promising for the construction of photovoltaic devices with high power density and ultrathin thickness.[140] In the following section, we will elaborate the solar energy conversion application of 2D MDCs with emphasis on solar cell devices, including Schottky barrier solar cells, heterojunction solar cells, organic solar cells (OSCs), dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) and quantum dotsensitized solar cells (QDSCs). In addition, we will also present some typical examples of 2D MDCs for PEC cell application.

sections.heading: 6.1.1. Schottky Barrier and Heterojunction Solar Cells
sections.text: Schottky barrier solar cell has a simple device structure consisting of conductive substrate/photoactive semiconductor/ metal contact, where both n-type and p-type semiconductors can be used as the photoactive layers.[141] Since 2D MDC nanosheets can be readily prepared in large scale by solution-based synthetic approaches, a bulk heterojunction solar cell with the device structure of indium tin oxide (ITO)/TiO2/WS2/poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT)/Au was successfully constructed by using WS2 nanosheets as the photoactive layer.[142] Briefly, monolayer and few-layer WS2 nanoflakes were prepared by sonication of bulk WS2 in acetone. The resultant WS2 nanoflake was then coated on TiO2 NPs to serve as the electron acceptor, and P3HT was used as the hole conductor. Interestingly, it was found the photovoltaic performance of the heterojunction solar cell was related to the thickness of WS2 nanoflake-coated porous TiO2 films. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) was increased from 1.9% to 2.6% with increasing the film thickness from 7.1 to 12.7 μm. Similarly, MoS2-based heterojunction solar cell was also successfully fabricated, which exhibited a PCE of 1.3%.[143] It is believed that further improvement of PCE can be expected after an indepth understanding of the charge transport process and recombination mechanism at the TiO2/2D MDCs/P3HT interfaces.

Surface modification of MDC nanosheets is an effective way to further enhance the performance and stability of OPV cells.[147] As a typical example, the MoO3 NP-decorated fewlayer MoS2 nanosheets (MoO3-MoS2), prepared via an one-pot oxidation/exfoliation method, were used as the HTL in OPV cells.[147a] This device exhibited PCE of 6.9%, which is higher than that of MoS2 (1.5%) or MoO3 (5.2%) alone. Importantly, this device also showed better stability than that of commercial HTL, i.e., poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesu lfonate) (PEDOT:PSS). In addition, Au NP-decorated ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets (Au-MoS2) have also been integrated into OPV cells.[147b] Combining the hole extraction property of 2D MoS2 layer and the plasmonic effect of Au NPs, the OPV cell based on the Au-MoS2 composite exhibited increased short-circuit current density and PCE.
Band engineering of 2D MDC nanosheets has been also proved effective to improve the performance of OPV cells, which was realized by a simple UV-ozone post treatment.[145a,d,148] The treated 2D MDC nanosheets composing of metal oxides and sulfides result in the decrease of defect sites along with the increase of work function of the MDC nanosheets, which benefits from the formation of Ohmic contact between 2D MDC nanosheets and the donor materials. Therefore, the UV-treated MDC nanosheets showed enhanced device performance in OPV cells due to a striking enhancement of their open voltage.[145a,d,148] In addition, it was also found that the modulation of work function of 2D MDC nanosheets could
be accomplished by either p- or n-doping treatment.[149] The usage of p-doped MoS2 nanosheets as the HTL in normal OPV cells and n-doped nanosheets as the ETL in inverted OPV cells improved the photovoltaic performance compared to untreated MoS2 nanosheets.
Besides MoS2 and WS2 nanosheets, NbSe2 and TaS2 nanosheets can also be integrated into OPV cells.[145b,150] For example, 2D NbSe2 nanosheets prepared by the lithium intercalation-assisted exfoliation method were directly used as the HTLs in OPV cells without further thermal annealing treatment.[145b] PCE of 8.10% was achieved for this device, superior to that based on the traditional HTL of thermal evaporated MoO3 film. The outstanding performance was ascribed to the unique layered structure of 2D NbSe2 nanosheets with a lower trap density, which could provide a surface dipole to promote charge extraction and suppress charge recombination. In another example, Le et al. demonstrated that TaS2 nanosheets and UV-ozone treated TaS2 nanosheets could serve as HTLs in normal OPV cells and ETLs in inverted OPV cells, respectively.[150]

The light absorption property and band gap energy of MDC nanosheets can be tuned by changing their layer numbers, making it possible to form a type-II band alignment[152] between MDC nanosheets and metal oxide scaffold to serve as photoanodes. Furthermore, the abundant edge sites of 2D MDC nanosheets render them as catalytic electrode for the redox couple regeneration. In an earlier report, Thomalla et al. investigated the photosensitization effect of electrode based on few-layer WS2 nanosheet-coated nanostructured TiO2, in which the photocurrent was generated due to the injection of electron from WS2 to TiO2.[153] More recently, Du et al. fabricated a DSSC using the chemical bath deposited few-layer MoS2 nanosheets as sensitized layer.[154] The light absorption range of TiO2 photoanode was extended to visible light region after incorporation of the MoS2 nanosheets. A DSSC device was assembled by using I−/I3− electrolyte for hole transportation and Pt-coated fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glass as the CE, in which a PCE of 1.08% was achieved under optimal condition. Obviously, the photovoltaic performance of this DSSC device is much lower than that of the traditional one using dye-sensitized TiO2 photoanode, e.g., the PCE of 6–10% for DSSC devices based on di-tetrabutylammonium cis-bis(isothiocyanato) bis(2,2′-bipyridyl-4,4′-dicarboxylato)ruthenium(II) (N719).[151b] This might be attributed to the weak interaction between MoS2 nanosheets and TiO2. Notably, the intimate contact between dye and TiO2 matrix by forming chemical bonding between them can enable the efficient electron injection in DSSCs.[151c] Therefore, the interfacial engineering of photovoltaic devices based on 2D MDC nanosheet and TiO2 is essential to further improve their performance. Currently, the use of 2D MDC nanosheets as sensitizers in DSSCs is still in an early stage, and more efforts need to be devoted to optimizing the photovoltaic performance.
Although only a few papers reported the utilization of 2D MDC nanosheets as the light absorber layer in DSSCs, solution-processed 2D MDC nanosheets have been widely used as electrocatalysts at CEs to replace the expensive Pt in DSSCs. In 2011, Wu et al. reported that MoS2 and WS2 particles can be used as CE catalysts, which showed high electrocatalytic activity for tri-iodide reduction. High PCEs of 7.59% and 7.73% were achieved on MoS2 and WS2 CEs, respectively, which were close to or even superior to that of the Pt CE (7.64%).[155] Moreover, 2D MoS2 nanosheets obtained by the lithium intercalation assisted exfoliation method could also be used as Pt-free electrocatalysts. After spin-coating on FTO with suitable thermal treatment, the MoS2 nanosheet film displayed a Pt-like electrocatalytic activity and achieved PCE of 7.35% as CE in a DSSC device.[156] Additionally, the MoS2 nanosheet film deposited FTO also showed higher transmittance compared to the conventional Pt CE, making it possible to serve as CE in bifacial DSSCs to enhance light harvesting from double side light penetration. Furthermore, the photovoltaic performance of MoS2 and WS2 nanosheets could be further enhanced by introduction of second additives, such as graphene or CNTs, which benefits from both the intrinsically high electrocatalytic activity of 2D MDC nanosheets and high conductivity of carbon materials.[157] In addition, Ibrahem et al. reported the exfoliation of
bulk NbSe2 into different morphologies, including nanosheets, nanorods and NPs, through a wet-chemical method by controlling the milling time. The DSSCs using NbSe2 nanosheets as the CE achieved the best device performance with a PCE up to 7.73%, superior to that of Pt-based CE (7.01%) and much higher than that of NbSe2 nanorods (5.05%) and NbSe2 NPs (6.27%).[158] Recently, SnS2 and FeSe2 nanosheets prepared by a hot injection method were also used as Pt-free CEs in DSSCs, achieving PCEs of 7.64% and 7.53%, respectively.[159] Although 2D MDCs are promising as electrocatalysts in DSSCs, there is few report on the long-term stability of those DSSCs when operated under continuous light illumination. It would be practically competitive for 2D MDC-based DSSCs if their durabilities are superior to the Pt-based DSSCs.
Besides DSSCs, Barpuzary et al. studied the application of MoS2 nanosheet-decorated Cu2ZnSnS4 microsphere as the CE for QDSCs.[160] With only 1.0 wt% loading of MoS2, the QDSC device exhibited a maximum PCE of 4.58%, higher than that of bare Cu2ZnSnS4 (4.17%). The improved performance could be ascribed to the bridge effect of MoS2 nanosheets, which might interconnect with the Cu2ZnSnS4 microspheres to promote the charge transport on CE. In addition, the in situ hydrothermal sulfurization has also been adopted to grow MoS2 nanosheets on Mo foil (MoS2-Mo), which exhibited good electrocatalytic activity for the polysulfide reduction in aqueous solution.[161] The obtained MoS2-Mo electrode can be directly used as CE in a QDSC and PCE of 1.21% was achieved, higher than that of the QDSC based on Pt (0.85%) and Au (0.75%) CEs. Considering the similar device structure and work principle of DSSCs and QDSCs, the application of MDC nanosheets or their composites as electrocatalysts in QDSCs is worthy of exploration in the near future. Importantly, understanding the difference between iodide/triiodide (I−/I3−) redox couple in DSSCs and sulfide/polysulfide (S2–/Sn2–) redox couple in QDSCs is helpful for the relevant study.

sections.heading: 6.2. Photoelectrochemical (PEC) Cells
sections.text:
PEC cells can store the solar energy in the form of chemical fuels, such as hydrogen. Currently, splitting of water into hydrogen and oxygen through a PEC process is a hot topic. Although many promising electrode materials have been prepared for PEC cells, their conversion efficiencies are still unsatisfactory to meet the requirements for the commercial application.[1d] MDCs with unique optical properties have been regarded as potential photoelectrode materials for PEC cells. The early work on PEC cells using vapor transport fabricated single-crystalline WSe2 crystal as photoanode achieved high efficiency of 17.1%.[162] Recently, 2D MDC nanosheets for PEC cell application have also been explored. For example, it was found that the film thickness of 2D MoS2 nanosheets plays an important role in the PEC performance.[163] Monolayer MoS2 film gave the highest photocurrent and the absorbed photon-tocurrent efficiencies, while both of them dropped dramatically with the increase of film thickness although the light absorption enhanced greatly. The worse PEC performance of thick MoS2 film was ascribed to the long charge transport pathway, leading to favorable charge recombination for thick films.

Recently, our group found that the PEC performance of chemically exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets can be further enhanced by decorating Au NPs on their surface.[164] The phase transformation of MoS2 occurring during the preparation of MoS2 nanosheets, i.e., from semiconducting 2H phase to metallic 1T phase, also made the exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets attractive for being used as the noble-metal-free cocatalyst in PEC cells. The photocurrent of this device increased from 100 to 370 μA/cm2 at 0.8 V after loading with 3 wt% of Au NPs, which could benefit the charge separation on MoS2 nanosheets. In addition, Jin et al. reported that the 1T-MoS2 nanosheet-coated planar p-type Si photocathode prepared by drop-casting can improve the performance of solar-driven hydrogen production, which is due to the reduced carrier recombination dynamics and efficient charge carrier separation of the MoS2-Si photocathode.[165] Moreover, the enhanced PEC performance was also realized in CdS QD-sensitized TiO2 mesoporous electrode after it was decorated with metallic 1T-MoS2 nanosheets as the cocatalyst.[166]
Unlike n-type photocurrent generation of MoS2 nanosheets in a PEC cell, p-type behavior was observed in self-assembled 2D WSe2 thin films. For example, Yu et al. reported a novel space-confined self-assembled (SCSA) deposition method for the fabrication of homogeneous WSe2 thin film (SCSA-WSe2 film, Figure 13a).[167] This method is based on the self-assembly of WSe2 flakes at the interface of two immiscible solvents of WSe2. Large thin films of WSe2 that are parallelly aligned on the FTO substrate were obtained by the SCSA method (Figure 13b,c). In contrast, the WSe2 thin film with a random orientation was also prepared by the traditional deposition method, referred to as AC-WSe2 film (Figure 13d,e). The two types of WSe2 thin films were used as photoelectrodes for PEC cells after deposition of Pt films on them. The photoelectrode
of Pt-coated SCSA-WSe2 film exhibited a steady photocurrent of 0.78 ± 0.17 mA/cm2, while a quick decay of photocurrent was observed for that of the Pt-coated AC-WSe2 film (Figure 13f). The superior performance of the photoelectrode based on SCSA-WSe2 film was ascribed to the improved contact of SCSAWSe2 film and the conducing FTO substrate, which benefits the charge transport and collection. It is believed that the proposed SCSA deposition technique could be extended to fabricate other 2D MDC-based thin film photoelectrodes.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion and Perspective
sections.text:
Recent progress in high-yield, massive production of 2D MDCbased nanomaterials via solution-based approaches allows them to be easily integrated as electrodes into various types of energy storage/conversion applications, such as rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors, electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution, and solar energy conversion. Due to their unique structural features and extraordinary chemical properties, excellent performances have been achieved on some of 2D MDC-based nanomaterials. For example, metallic 1T-WS2 nanosheet exhibited high electrocatalytic activity toward HER,[17a] which is potentially used to replace precious Pt-based catalysts. Moreover, the metallic 1T-MoS2 nanosheet has been demonstrated to be a promising electrode material for supercapacitors,[18] which showed excellent volumetric energy and power density values, Coulombic efficiency and cycling stability at high voltage (3.5 V) in nonaqueous organic electrolytes.

Therefore, the first challenge lies in how to realize the high-yield and massive production of single-layer MDCs with controlled size, defects, crystal phase and compositions. (2) As for batteries, the large loss of capacity has been always observed in the first cycle, especially at a high rate, although various electrode materials based on 2D MDCs have been developed for LIBs/SIBs. Therefore, the second challenge remaining in this field is how to overcome the poor Coulombic efficiency in the first cycle by rational designing the electrode materials based on 2D MDCs. (3) As for supercapacitors, although the usage of pure 2D MDC nanosheets for supercapacitor electrodes is of great importance for the fabrication of flexible supercapacitors for next-generation electronic devices, it is still limited by the poor performance. Therefore, the third challenge is how to achieve excellent performance based on pure 2D MDC electrodes by rationally designed materials with favorable structural features. (4) As for solar cells, although the strong light absorption was observed in 2D MDCs, their solar energy conversion efficiencies are still low, compared to that of traditional silicon-based solar cells. Therefore, the last but not the least challenge is how to optimize the configuration of solar cell devices based on 2D MDCs to achieve better performance.
Considering the short history, the research on solution-processed 2D MDCs and their composites for energy storage/conversion is still at its early stage and there are still many opportunities. Currently, 2D MDC-based materials that have been intensively explored mainly focus on MoS2 and WS2 nanosheets. It is noteworthy that MDCs represent a large group of materials, including MoS2, WS2, TiS2, TaS2, MoSe2, WSe2, MoTe2, ZrS2, ReS2, etc., which have similar structural features but versatile chemical and electronic properties. One of the most straightforward but promising opportunities in this area is the exploration of these novel 2D MDCs and their functional composites as electrode materials for energy-related applications. From the material point of view of 2D MDC composites, the most commonly used matrices for hybridization with 2D MDCs are carbonaceous nanomaterials, such as graphene, CNTs, carbon, fibers and amorphous carbon. There are many other materials have shown great potential for energy-related applications, such as metal oxides, metal hydroxides and conductive polymers. Therefore, another future direction lies in the combination of these materials with 2D MDCs to form functional composites, which could be a fascinating strategy to realize the optimal performance of energy storage/conversion devices.

This greatly accelerates the development of novel electrode materials with unique structural characteristics and functions to achieve a further breakthrough of energy storage/conversion systems.[4a,7] Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials, especially graphene, have drawn vast attention and shown great promise for a wide range of applications.[8] Inspired by the great achievements of graphene-related researches in the past decade,[9] a number of graphene analogs have been synthesized and explored, especially 2D metal dichalcogenides (MDCs), which represent a big family of compounds with a generalized formula of MX2. Due to the ultrathinness and 2D morphology, 2D MDCs with singleor few-layer thickness have shown some extraordinary properties in contrast to their bulk counterparts. First, some of the 2D MDCs exhibit layer-dependent bandgap. For example, an indirect band gap of 1.3 eV in bulk MoS2 converts into a direct band gap of 1.8 eV in the single-layer MoS2. Second, similar to graphene, the ultrathin thickness and 2D morphology enable 2D MDCs with ultrahigh specific surface area compared to their bulk counterparts,[12] making them promising for those surface-active applications, such as electrocatalysis and supercapacitors. Third, 2D MDCs possess high flexibility and good mechanical strength in contrast to their bulk counterparts due to the unique 2D structural features.[13] Owing to these extraordinary properties, 2D MDCs have been explored for various promising applications in electronics/optoelectronics, sensors and biomedicine.[14] Specifically, the appealing features of 2D MDCs including highly exposed active edge sites, large specific surface area and easy to be intercalated by other guest materials render them favorable for energy storage/conversion applications like rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors, electrocatalytic hydrogen generation and solar cells.[15] Another important feature of MDCs is that the bulk MDCs can crystallize into different types of polymorphs and stacking polytypes (a specific case of polymorphism) based on the different coordination modes between transition metals and The development of renewable energy storage and conversion devices is one of the most promising ways to address the current energy crisis, along with the global environmental concern. The exploration of suitable active materials is the key factor for the construction of highly efficient, highly stable, lowcost and environmentally friendly energy storage and conversion devices. The ability to prepare two-dimensional (2D) metal dichalcogenide (MDC) nanosheets and their functional composites in high yield and large scale via various solution-based methods in recent years has inspired great research interests in their utilization for renewable energy storage and conversion applications. Here, we will summarize the recent advances of solutionprocessed 2D MDCs and their hybrid nanomaterials for energy storage and conversion applications, including rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors, electrocatalytic hydrogen generation and solar cells. Moreover, based on the current progress, we will also give some personal insights on the existing challenges and future research directions in this promising field.
